titlestmt.titleproper: Inventory of O.41 - Collection of Lists and Documentation Regarding Those Who Perished and Those Who Were Persecuted During the Holocaust Period O.41
titlestmt.author: Yad Vashem Archives

did.unittitle: O.41 - Collection of Lists and Documentation Regarding Those Who Perished and Those Who Were Persecuted During the Holocaust Period

scopecontent.p: O.41 - Collection of Lists and Documentation Regarding Those Who Perished and Those Who Were Persecuted During the Holocaust Period The collection is mainly comprised of lists of Jews who perished or were persecuted during the Holocaust period. These lists come from many diverse sources, various types and different languages. The lists of those who perished were compiled and prepared by official sources and established bodies, as well as by family members, friends and fellow townspeople. Besides the lists of those who perished, the Collection also contains concurrent lists of those who were deported and persecuted, i. e. lists compiled during World War II in the camps and in the ghettos. Additionally, there are lists that were constructed during the early days after the liberation and through the late 1990s. A large number of the lists were prepared and compiled in order to commemorate and memorialize; they reflect the strong desire of the survivors to preserve the memory of those who perished. In the various lists there is diverse information regarding those who perished and those who were persecuted besides their names. In the Collection, there are also many certificates and authorizations issued by various organizations throughout Europe at the request of close family members and friends searching for their loved ones after the war. These certificates and authorizations provide information regarding their fate during the Holocaust. This record group can be described as a database of scores of thousands of names of Jews who perished or were persecuted during the Holocaust.

scopecontent.p: List of Jews from Esztergom who perished, 1944-1945, based on the monument erected in memory of the local Holocaust victims The list also contains the names of those in the labor battalions (p. 1057) who perished. The file also contains a letter of thanks written by the chairperson of the Hungarian Jewish Communities Committee in 1949 to the person who submitted the material, Oedoen Schatz, thanking him for his efforts in memorializing those who perished.
The list/s contain approximately 516 names

scopecontent.p: List of Jews from Mszana Dolna, prepared by the Germans, 15/06/1942, with the names of the Jews murdered, 19/08/1942, and buried in a mass grave in Mszana Dolna indicated List includes the names of 881 Jews murdered in Mszana Dolna, 19/08/1942 and buried in a mass grave in Mszana Dolna, as well as the names of other Jews from Mszana Dolna and the Mszana Dolna area who were deported to labor camps, mainly to a quarry in Limanova where most of the deportees perished.
The list/s contain approximately 1029 names

scopecontent.p: List of Jews from Vilna and the Vilna vicinity murdered in Schoemberg camp, 1944-1945, who were buried in the cemetery in Schoemberg The list was published by The Vilna Association for Assistance and Rescue, September, 1963. The booklet includes Forwards written by Batia Popka and Mordchai Bernstein who recall the story of hundreds of Jews from Vilna who were brought to the camp and murdered there and the Camp Graveyard where 1,755 Jews who were murdered are buried. The call-out number of the booklet in Yad Vashem Library is 77-0653.

did.unittitle: Confirmation by various official organizations, regarding the fate of European Jews during the Holocaust

scopecontent.p: Confirmation by various official organizations, regarding the fate of European Jews during the Holocaust Page 1264 – Letter of testimony from the municipal council of Taurage, sent to Iosif Beder, regarding the murder of his family members, 13/09/1941; pp. 1266-1272 – Documentation collected by K. Gluzman, regarding the funeral and establishment of a monument in memory of victims of the Holocaust from Rybnista; pp. 1274-1275 – Announcement regarding the death of Petr Neymark in combat, 18/08/1944; pp. 1276-1277 – Documentation from ITS regarding the fate of Samuel Billig, born in Stanislawow, who was deported from Drancy to Auschwitz, 14/08/1942, and perished; p. 1278 – Death certificate of Abram-Marcu Itcu-Comanesteanu, from Iasi, who perished on a death train, 30/06/1941; p. 1279 – Documentation from the Jewish community of Saloniki regarding the fate of Rafael Ruben, who perished during the Holocaust; p. 1280 – Confirmation of the murder of Sara Tziporina and her children, in Dobryanka, 12/1941; p. 1281 – Death certificates of the Stein family members, from Cluj, who perished in Auschwitz, 06/1944; pp. 1282-1283 – Document of soldier Boruch Rajman, from Warsaw, who was drafted into the Polish Army, 1920; pp. 1284-1285 – Death certificate of Lazar Adler, from Kassel, who perished in Theresienstadt, 04/12/1942; p. 1286 – Announcement regarding the death of Josif Averbukh, born in Proskurov, in combat, 27/03/1942; pp. 1287-1294 – Letter of testimony from Yakov Goldberg, from Odessa, regarding the mass murder of Jews in Bogdanovka, 10/1941; p. 1295 – Declaration regarding the death of Paul Walter, from Vienna, who was deported to Auschwitz, 1942; pp. 1296-1299 – Declaration regarding the death of Rene Mendl, from Vienna, who was deported to Minsk, 02/05/1942; p. 1301 – Death certificates of Lev and Basya Frumkin, who were murdered, 05/09/ 1942; p. 1302 – Confirmation of death of Siegfrid Prager, who perished in Auschwitz, 31/12/1943; pp. 1303-1304 – Letter of testimony of Lew Steinhauser, regarding the murder of Ester Jacubson, in Vilna, 06/09/ 1941; pp. 1305, 1318 – Documentation regarding the fate of the Arnheim couple, from Berlin, who were deported to the Theresienstadt Ghetto, 16/08/1943, and perished in Auschwitz camp; p. 1306 – Confirmation regarding the death of Leo Fasal, 1930, and the deportation of Frantisek Fasal from Prague to the Theresienstadt Ghetto, 03/08/1942, and his deportation to Auschwitz, 26/10/1943; pp. 1307-1309 – Personal documentation of Leon and Kajla Frank, who were deported to Auschwitz, 20/09/1942, and perished; pp. 1310-1311 – Letter of verification of residents of Bogdanovka, Stavropol region, regarding the murder of the relatives of Khava Rakhanaeva, 22/10/1942; pp. 1312-1315 – Personal documentation of Benjamin and Isaak Valensi, who were deported to Majdanek, 23/03/1943, and perished; p. 1316 – Personal documentation of Anette Ben Arros, who perished in Bergen-Belsen, 25/05/ 1945; p. 1317 – Documentation regarding the fate of Maurice Wahiche, born in Alexandria, who was deported to Auschwitz, 27/03/1942, and perished; pp. 1319-1321 – Documentation from ITS regarding the fate of Ernst and Martha Lewent, who were deported from Berlin to Auschwitz, 17/05/1943; p. 1322 – Death certificate of Zofie Philippova, from Fuerth, who perished in Theresienstadt, 01/10/1942; p. 1323 – Documentation from ITS regarding the fate of Jean Grinberg, who perished in Stutthof camp, 13/09/1944; pp. 1324-1334 – Personal documentation of Elias Weinberg, born in Bucharest, who was deported to Auschwitz via Drancy, 07/12/1943; pp. 1335-1336 – Confirmation by ITS regarding the deportation of Erhart Hirsch, born in Aachen, to Auschwitz via Drancy, 28/08/1942; p. 1337 – Confirmation of death of Arlette Maryse Starck, from Paris, who perished in Auschwitz, 28/09/1942; pp. 1338-1341 – Personal documentation of Mosez Hollaender, born in Sucha, who perished in Melk an der Donau camp, 05/03/1945; p. 1342 – Confirmation of death of Bertha Cohn-Biedermann, who was deported from Berlin to Riga, 15/08/1942; p. 1343 – Confirmation of death of Heymann Levy, born in Aach, who perished in Auschwitz, 09/11/1942; pp. 1344-1345 – Confirmation of death of Charles Tiepenbrunner, born in Klasno, who perished in Majdanek, 11/03/1943; p. 1346 – Confirmation of death of Lotte Jaruslawsky, who perished in Auschwitz; p. 1347 – Confirmation of death of Robert Gutmann, who perished in Berlin, 04/11/1942; pp. 1348-1352 – Documentation regarding the fate of Kurt Gutmann, from Sayn, who perished during the Holocaust; pp. 1353-1365 – Documentation regarding the fate of Jews from various places who were deported and perished during the Holocaust; pp. 1366-1369 – Documentation regarding the fate of members of the Levy family who were deported to Auschwitz via Drancy, 17/12/1943, and perished; p. 1370 – Death certificate of Chaja Sara Teichmann, who perished in Breslau, 10/06/1944; pp. 1371-1381 – Personal history and documentation regarding the fate of Karl Teichmann, from Germany, and his family members.

did.unittitle: List of Jews who perished in the Zeitz labor camp, 1944-1945 and were buried in the Gera cemetery

custodhist.p: The materials were transferred to Yad Vashem byזליקוביץ מנדל

scopecontent.p: List of Jews who perished in the Zeitz labor camp, 1944-1945 and were buried in the Gera cemetery All the Jews in the Gera (Thueringen, Germany) ghetto were deported to different death camps where most of them perished. The remains of 446 Jews who perished in Rehmsdorf and Zeitz sub-camps and in Buchenwald are buried in the Ostfriedhof cemetery in Gera. Their names are commemorated on a memorial stone. The names of 89 Jews appear on this list; they are numbered among the 446 victims buried in the Gera cemetery.
The list/s contain approximately 89 names

did.unittitle: Confirmation that Svi Max and Svi Elizaveta were killed by the Nazi's during 12-15/08/1942

custodhist.p: The materials were transferred to Yad Vashem byיזרסקי אליהו\

scopecontent.p: Confirmation that Svi Max and Svi Elizaveta were killed by the Nazi's during 12-15/08/1942 Confirmation from the Stavropol District Archive's that without a doubt, Svi Max and Svi Elizaveta were killed by the Nazi's. They're bodies were identified in a grave near the Stavropol Airport after the war. This information was revealed during a war crimes inquiry in the Stavropol district. The document was based on the material found in the archive: FR-1368, op.1, d.152, 1.11-15; FR-1686, op.1,d.3,1.7ob.

scopecontent.p: Documentation regarding the fate of the Jewish communities in the Kamenets Podolsk region during and after the Holocaust; and lists of Jews from Kunev who perished Includes: -List of cities and towns in the Kamenets-Podolsk region where Jews were murdered. After the war some of the communities were reestablished and others not. -List of Jewish Red Army soldiers from Kunev, who died in battle, or were considered missing. -List of Kunev residents who perished. The lists were prepared by Loifer Moisey Volfovich.

scopecontent.p: Documentation regarding the fate of Elias Loewenwirth, born in Irsava, who perished in Dachau camp, 11/02/1945 Confirmations issued by the Swiss Red Cross organization, the Union of Jewish Communities in Italy, and the French Embassy in Germany, 1956-1957, regarding the fate of Elias Loewenwirth, who was detained in Italy and deported to Fossoli di Carpi camp, 1944 and then his transfer to Auschwitz, Bergen-Belsen, Sachsenhausen and Dachau camp, where he perished, 11/02/1945.

scopecontent.p: Documentation regarding the fate of the Mayer, Kadisch and Kolitz family members from Germany who perished during the Holocaust - Letters issued by the UNRRA Missing Persons Bureau, regarding the fate of Emma Anna (Drexler) Meyer, who was born in Czechoslovakia during the Holocaust; - Letters issued by the UNRRA Missing Persons Bureau, 03/06/1946 and 19/06/1946, regarding the fate of Helene Wertheimer, who stayed in Jordanbad DP camp after the liberation; - Confirmation issued by the Jewish community in Berlin, 02/12/1948, regarding the fate of Paula (Block) Kadisch, Rudolf Kadisch and Gertrud (Bresch) Kolitz, who were deported to Auschwitz, 1943.

did.unittitle: Register of prisoners of Mauthausen and sub-camps

acqinfo.p: The reference code for of the materials atNATIONAL ARCHIVES, USAis A 3355

custodhist.p: The materials were transferred to Yad Vashem byFriedman Jehuda Leib

scopecontent.p: The CD contained 2 Access 2000 files containing the names of all the people who perished in Mauthausen, and only the Jewish people amongst them. The files are kept in the "General Archive", sub-folder Mauthausen. Six microfilms from the American National Archive were scanned. The scans are kept in "video in on Kdamdfus1", in folder NARA. The microfilms include the Totenbuch Mauthausen for the years of 1939-1940, which used as a legal evidence in the Nuremberg Trials, names lists and lists of people who perished (noting date and place of birth, and the lists of the deceased include date of death) prepared by the Americans in 1945.

did.unittitle: Documentation regarding Lion Slagter, born in Rotterdam, the Netherlands, 1913, and Rebekka (Jedwab) Slagter, born in Cologne, Germany, 1914, from 1943-1955

custodhist.p: The materials were transferred to Yad Vashem byחיה אדלמן

scopecontent.p: Documentation regarding Lion Slagter, born in Rotterdam, the Netherlands, 1913, and Rebekka (Jedwab) Slagter, born in Cologne, Germany, 1914, from 1943-1955 Documents regarding the fate of Lion Slagter, born in Rotterdam, the Netherlands, 1913, and Rebekka (Jedwab) Slagter, born in Cologne, Germany, 1914, from 1943-1955; labor booklet issued to Lion Slagter in Westerbork camp, 23/10/1943; declaration by the rabbi of Arnhem, Rabbi Levison, that he was present at the death of Rivka bat Yishaia HaKohen Jedwab, wife of Yehuda Slagter, in the Bergen-Belsen hospital on Gimel Shevat 5705 (17 January 1945); confirmation by the Dutch Red Cross that Rebekka Slagter-Jedwab perished in Bergen-Belsen; confirmation by the Dutch Red Cross, 06/09/1955, that Lion Slagter was evacuated to Bergen-Belsen and liberated at Trobitz, April 1945.

scopecontent.p: List of Jews from Hungary who perished after the liberation of Mauthausen and Gunskirchen camps and were buried in the Wels camp cemetery, 05-07/1945 The Jews' death was due to weakness and disease during the first weeks following the liberation; reburial was done in orderly cemeteries in Wels and Hoersing, with registration of their names and the number of the grave; most of the people buried here were originally from Hungary. Detailed lists appear in various websites, and include an additional 500 Jews who were buried in the area; following are links to the websites: http://www.findagrave.com/cgi-bin/fg.cgi?page=cr&GSvcid=66708&CRid=2210340&pt=Stadtfriedhof%20Wels& http://www.findagrave.com/cgi-bin/fg.cgi?page=cr&GSvcid=66708&CRid=2210340&pt=Stadtfriedhof%20Linz%2C%20St.%20Martin& 20Wels&
The list/s contain approximately 850 names

did.unittitle: Documentation regarding the Rashid Ali riots in Baghdad, May-June 1941

scopecontent.p: Documentation regarding the Rashid Ali riots in Baghdad, May-June 1941 Pages 2-178: Research by Dr. Tuvia Ashkenazi, published, 1960, regarding Iraq Jewry during the Arab rule, 1914-1960, and the riots in Baghdad, May-June 1941; included with the research is a list of the people who were murdered; Pages 180-204: Research by Avraham Tavina regarding the Shavuot riots [Rashid Ali riots], June 1941, published in "Golim ve'Geulim (Babylonian Jewry)" ("Exiled and Redeemed"), issue no. 3, 1977; Pages 205-251: Pamphlet published by Rachamim Gabai, 2000, with testimonies of survivors who lived during the period of the [Rashid Ali] riots, June 1941. Note: The page numbers of the scan do not necessarily match the numbers on the pages of the original document.

scopecontent.p: 15 lists of people who perished, and memoirs, articles and photographs regarding the history of the Holocaust in the Cherkassy region Lists of Jews who were murdered in various places in the Cherkassy region; memoirs, testimonies, articles and statistical data regarding the mass murders of Jews that took place in the region, including Jewish Red Army soldiers who died in battle and details about local residents who were active on behalf of the rescue of Jews, 1941-1943.

did.unittitle: List of 97 names of people who perished and of survivors, from Hungary, Germany, the Netherlands, Poland and Romania, taken from 11 books

custodhist.p: The materials were transferred to Yad Vashem byרחל בן-אליעזר

scopecontent.p: List of 97 names of people who perished and of survivors, from Hungary, Germany, the Netherlands, Poland and Romania, taken from 11 books The names of the books are: 1. "Let Us Not Forget" by Irene Teger; 2. "My Turbulent Life" by Arthur M. Ingster; 3. "Oma's True Story (The Story of My Life)" by Rose de Liema; 4. "Survival from Nazi Persecution" by Marie Rebhun; 5. "Our Journey in the Valley of Tears" by Andrzej and Karolina Jus; 6. "Middle Andzia" by Anda Meisels Rosen; 7. "My Darkest Years" by James Bachner; 8. "The First Morning Light" by Yaakov Barzilai; 9. "My Star" by Felicja Nowak; 10. "Live, Remember, Tell the World" by Leah Kaufman and Sheina Medwed; 11. "From Kletsk to Siberia" by Alter Pekier.
The list/s contain approximately 97 names

did.unittitle: Personal documentation of Johanna Rosenthal, her husband Jacob Rosenthal and their daughter Ingeborg

acqinfo.p: The material was aquired by Yad Vashem fromSAECHSISCHES STAATSARCHIV LEIPZIG

custodhist.p: The materials were transferred to Yad Vashem byשולמית קליין

scopecontent.p: Personal documentation of Johanna Rosenthal, her husband Jacob Rosenthal and their daughter Ingeborg Deportation of Rosenthal from Leipzig to Theresienstadt, 17 February 1943; murder of Rosenthal in Auschwitz; death of her husband Jacob Rosenthal in Leipzig on 04 November 1942; aliya of their daughter Ingeborg to Eretz Israel in 1936; The documentation also includes: Document from 1943 on the German order that Johanna Wien Rosenthal sell her home in Leipzig before her deportation East; Document confirming the deportation of Rosenthal to Theresienstadt on 17 February 1943; Document stating that Jacob Rosenthal died in Leipzig on 04 November 1942; An additional document confirming the death of Jacob Rosenthal; Cards with details of the Rosenthal couple prepared by the Israelitische Religionsgemeinde zu Leipzig; Section of the list of Jews who died in Leipzig during the war including Jacob Rosenthal; Questionnaire filled out by Jacob Rosenthal for the Reichsvereinigung der Juden in Deutschland, National Association of Jews in Germany, 25 June 1940; Birth certificate of Ingeborg Rosenthal; Original German passport of Ingeborg issued on 08 October 1936 before her aliya to Eretz Israel.

scopecontent.p: Certificates and various documents regarding the fate of Etl and Eliezer Kagan, deported with their mothers to the Kovno Ghetto, where they disappeared, 1941, and personal documentation of Kagan family members from Marijampole, from before the war The documentation includes: - birth certificate of Dobe Kagan, the mother of the submitter of the material; - death certificate of her mother, Esther Kagan; - death certificate of her father, Michael Leizer Kagan; - birth certificate of Eliezer Kagan; - birth certificate of Etl Kagan; - document certifying the draft of Enoch Kagan (the brother of Dobe) into the Lithuanian Army, 1926; his disappearance, 1927; there is no information regarding his fate.

did.unittitle: Death certificates of Messod Cohen, born in Fez, Morocco, 1896, and his family members, residents of Paris, France, including a census record of the Jews in Morocco from the Casablanca municipality, with the name Raphael Cohen, dated, 03/10/1941

scopecontent.p: Death certificates of Messod Cohen, born in Fez, Morocco, 1896, and his family members, residents of Paris, France, including a census record of the Jews in Morocco from the Casablanca municipality, with the name Raphael Cohen, dated, 03/10/1941 Death certificates issued in Paris, 06-07 March 1947, confirming the detention of Messod Cohen and his deportation to Drancy, 03 June 1942; his deportation to Auschwitz, 22 June 1942; detention of his wife Jeanne (Radziejewski) Cohen, born in 1897, and their daughter Yolanda Fanny, born in 1924, [in Drancy], 23 January 1943; deportation of his wife and daughter to Auschwitz, 13 February, 1943; Note: Escape by Raphael Cohen (father [?] of the submitter of the material [?]) from Charleroi to his brother Messod Cohen in Paris, 1941; detention of Messod Cohen by the Gestapo, 03 June 1942; deportation of Messod to Drancy with his family; transfer to Auschwitz; rescue of Raphael Cohen with his wife and daughter; move of Raphael Cohen and his family to Spain, and their move to Morocco.

scopecontent.p: Confirmation by the Office for Health and Family Affairs in Brussels regarding the draft of Benjamin Laufmann to labor in the "Micka" company, 06-10/1942, and lists of Jews from Antwerp who labored in the "Micka" company, 1942 Document from the Office for Health and Family Affairs in Brussels confirming that Benjamin Laufmann was drafted to labor in the "Micka" company in the north of France, 06-10/1942, and that his wife is entitled to receive compensation; the document includes lists of Jews from Antwerp who labored in the "Micka" company, 1942; Benjamin Laufmann, born in Radauti, Romania, 01/05/1902, labored in the "Micka" company, 16/06/1942-31/10/1942, and his salary was sent to his wife in Antwerp; Lists of the laborers, prepared for the payment of a salary to their families, 09/07/1942-05/11/1942; next to each name are details regarding the wife's name, address and the amount of money earned by the laborer. Note: Benjamin Laufmann was deported to Auschwitz, 1942, where he perished.

scopecontent.p: Official documentation confirming that Salomon Hersz Sturm from Besancon, France, born in Tarnow, Poland, 1901, perished in Jawischowitz camp, 15/07/1944, and that his daughter Berthe, born in Besancon, France, 1931, perished in Auschwitz, 28/06/1943 The file includes a registration document issued to the Sturm family in Besancon, 09 March 1931, with details that were registered, 1947-1949, regarding the death of Salomon Hersz and Berthe and the dates of their deaths; The file includes a survivors certificate for Jozsef Kemeny from Budapest, born in Seregelyes, Hungary, 1903, testifying to his imprisonment in Mauthausen, 27/11/1944-05/05/1945 (the certificate was issued in Mauthausen DP camp, 27/06/1945).

scopecontent.p: Personal documentation: announcement that Berko Zilber, born in Hrubieszow, Poland, 1916, a Red Army soldier, fell in battle on 07 July 1943 Move of Berko Zilber with his wife Sara (Kanor) Zilber and two children, Margalit born in 1937 and Zvi born in 1939, to Kostroma under Soviet occupation after the division of Poland in 1939; draft to the Red Army, 1941; mortally wounded in combat in Leningrad, 07 July 1943; died from wounds in hospital after two days; The file also includes: Announcement that Berko Zilber died in battle on 07 July 1943; Letter sent to Sara Zilber by a battalion member on 10 August 1943 regarding the circumstances of his death including a military newspaper article dated 30 May 1943 on his heroism as the mortar battalion commander and an article written by Berko Zilber titled We Won't Let the Enemy Rest; pension eligibility card issued by the Red Army for Sara Zilber as a widow of a soldier who fell in battle; confirmation by the NKVD on the service of Berko Zilber in the Red Army as the mortar battalion commander, 31 December 1942.

custodhist.p: The materials were transferred to Yad Vashem byאסתר קופל

scopecontent.p: Documentation regarding the Glueckstein and Kopel family members from Kitzingen, and their fate during the Holocaust Documentation regarding the deportation of the Glueckstein family from Kitzingen to Poland; death certificate of Julius Glueckstein, who perished in Sachsenhausen camp, 28 May 1942; list of inmates who were executed the same day; list of Jews deported to Izbica, 23 March 1942; personal documents of Adolf Avraham Glueckstein, who made aliya to Eretz Israel, 1934; letter of testimony written by Gedalia Kopel in Sweden, 25 August 1945; Documentation regarding the Glueckstein family: - Documentation regarding the persecution of Jews during Kristallnacht, including the Glueckstein family; - Article written by Sali Bamberger Bar-Giora regarding Kristallnacht in Kitzingen, published in the "HaTzofeh" newspaper, 27 July 1984; - Official correspondence between district cities and the head office of the German Police in Berlin regarding the deportation of Jews with Polish citizenship, 1939 (including lists of people who must leave, including the Glueckstein family from Kitzengen); - List of 75 Jews from Kitzengen who were deported to Izbica, 23 March 1942; the list was prepared by the Secret Police in Wuerzburg; - List of Jewish inmates from Sachsenhausen camp who were shot or hung, including Julius Glueckstein, 28 May 1942; - Death certificate of Julius Glueckstein, dated, 20 July 1942 (executed by order of the commander of Sachsenhausen camp); - Aliya certificate and health card of Adolf Avraham Glueckstein, who made aliya to Eretz Israel, 1934; Documentation regarding the Kopel family: - Receipt given to Mendel Kopel for a donation made to the "Chochmei Lublin Yeshiva", 1933; - Letter by Gedalia Kopel in Sweden, which was sent to his family members in Eretz Israel, regarding his experiences during the Holocaust, written, 25 August 1945; - Yizkor list of the Kopel family members who perished, 23 June 1943 (written by Gedalia Kopel). Note: Julius Glueckstein was one of 96 Jews who were sentenced and deported to Sachsenhausen following an attack by the Herbert Baum group on the anti-Soviet propaganda exhibit in Berlin, 18 May 1942.

scopecontent.p: Personal documents of Ruth Zeira, regarding the sailing of the "Exodus" ship, 1947 and regarding her parents, Berthe and Harry Seckels from Köln, Germany, who were deported to Drancy and then to Auschwitz, August 1942 Included in the file: - Article from the "Hadashot" newspaper, published, 1987 regarding the story of Ruth and her husband Micky Zeira, who met on the "Exodus" ship and later married; - Information regarding Selma Seckels, an aunt of the submitter of the material, and her sister Edit; Note: The Seckles family owned a business before the war; Ruth's mother Berta Seckels perished in Auschwitz and her father Harry Seckels perished in Mauthausen.

scopecontent.p: Notification by the military commissioner in Vitebsk that Red Army soldier Yakov Novozhenetz was Missing In Action in battle, 09/1944 - Certification by the military commissioner in Vitebsk regarding the draft of Yakov Novozhenetz to the Red Army, 23 June 1941; document dated, 05 July 1941; - Notary's copy of the notification that was sent to Mikhla Novozhenetz by the military commissioner in Vitebsk, that her husband Red Army soldier Yakov Novozhenetz was Missing In Action atn the front, 09/1944; Note: Draft of Yakov Novozhenetz to the Red Army, at the outbreak of the war between Germany and the Soviet Union; evacuation of his wife and two children to Vitebsk; cutting off of contact between his children and their mother at the railroad station in Vitebsk; arrival of his children to Saratov, where they were sent to orphanages; their mother located her children several months later and they resided in Markshstadt, in the Saratov region, until the end of the war.

chronitem.event: Recruitment of Jews to the Polish army

custodhist.p: The materials were transferred to Yad Vashem byאליעזר גוט

scopecontent.p: Confirmation regarding the decision of the Court of Law in Pultusk to officially recognize the death of Srul Chaim Gut, and a birth certificate in the name of Srul Chaim Gut, issued in Przasnysz, 05/11/1949 - Confirmation regarding the decision of the Court of Law in Pultusk, 09/05/1946, to officially recognize the death of Srul Chaim Gut; confirmation issued, 28/07/1950; - Birth certificate in the name of Srul Chaim Gut, born in Jastrzebiec, Poland, 04/01/1911; certificate issued in Przasnysz, 05/11/1949 . Notes by Eliezer Gut, the submitter of the material: The family of Srul Chaim Gut resided in Pultusk. In 1934, Gut was drafted into the Polish Army. He died in battle against the German Army in 1939. Exact details regarding the circumstances of his death are unknown. After the German occupation of Poland, Gut's family members transferred to the Soviet side. During the war, they stayed in the Soviet Union, in the Kazan area.

scopecontent.p: Certification issued by the hospital in Kursk regarding the death of Red Army soldier Yakov Kore, 27/07/1941, and an entrance permit to the Third Army headquarters given to Kore, 25/04/1941 - Entrance permit to the Third Army headquarters, given to politruk (political commissar) Yakov Kore, 25/04/1941 ; - Two notorized copies of a certificate issued by the hospital in Kursk confirming the hospitalization of Yakov Kore in the hospital, 09-14/07/1941; transfer of Kore to a nerve clinic, where he died, 27/07/1941; notorized copies issued, 04/1947; Notes by the submitter of the material: Yakov Kore was born in Mogilev, 22/04/1915; his parents were Mina and Yevzel Kore; Yakov Kore's brother was Boris Kore; Yakov Kore served in the position of politruk (political commissar) in the Third Army headquarters, under the command of Major-General Pavlov; Yakov Kore was wounded on the first day of the war, in Grodno, and was hospitalized in the military hospital in Kursk, where he died, 27/07/ 1941.

controlaccess.subject: Jewish soldiers in the Red Army
Death certificates

custodhist.p: The materials were transferred to Yad Vashem byחייבטוב מניה - Khayvatov Mania

scopecontent.p: Notification that Red Army soldier Ilia Khayvatov, from Derbent, died in battle, 21/07/1943, and authorization regarding his draft into the Red Army, 02/03/1942 - Notification by the military commissioner in Derbent, 10/08/1943, that Red Army soldier Ilia Khayvatov died in battle, 21/07/1943, and was buried near the village of Petropoly in the Voroshilovgrad region; - Authorization issued in Derbent, 27/03/1942, regarding the draft of Ilia Khayvatov into the Red Army, 02/03/1942. Notes by Mania Khayvatov, the submitter of the material: Ilia Khayvatov was born in Dagestan in 1906, and his family resided in Derbent. His wife Tamara and their four children (Mania, Yaffa, Sara and Avraham) remained in Derbent during the war years.

did.unittitle: Announcement sent to Lea Alayeva, 12/12/1944, that her husband Achildy Mushiyev died in battle, 14/10/1943

controlaccess.subject: Jewish soldiers in the Red Army
Death certificates
Typhus
Keywords for visual sources

custodhist.p: The materials were transferred to Yad Vashem byמושייב אברם - Mushiyev Abram

scopecontent.p: Announcement sent to Lea Alayeva, 12/12/1944, that her husband Achildy Mushiyev died in battle, 14/10/1943 Included in the file: Certificate of disability belonging to Abram Musheyev (the son of Lea and Achildy Mushiyev), born in 1936; certificate issued, 15/07/1954; Note: Achildy Mushiyev was born in Chatirchi, Uzbekistan; he and his wife Lea (nee Alayeva) resided in Samarkand; Achildy worked as a shoemaker before the war, and his wife studied teaching; Achildy was drafted into the Red Army at the start of the war; his wife was forced to earn the livelihood for herself and their four children and she therefore left her teaching studies and started to work in shoemaking; two of her children, Ilich and Dora, died of typhus disease; Achildy served in Ukraine in the Kiev area, and was killed in battle; Lea survived the war and made aliya to Israel with her two children who remained alive; one of her children, Abram (the submitter of the material), became sick with meningitis and poliomyelitis during the war and he became disabled.

did.unittitle: Documentation regarding the first victims of the death march from Auschwitz, buried in a mass grave in the Brzeszcze cemetery

custodhist.p: The materials were transferred to Yad Vashem byגיל פארן

scopecontent.p: Documentation regarding the first victims of the death march from Auschwitz, buried in a mass grave in the Brzeszcze cemetery Burial of the corpses of 18 Auschwitz inmates, including 11 women, murdered by gunfire when the camp was being evacuated, 18/01/1945, and buried in the Brzeszcze cemetery: Instructions from the German mayor of Brzeszcze to the local residents to collect the corpses strewn along the roads and bury them, 19/01/1945; collection of 18 corpses [found] along the roads from Rajsko to Jawiszowice by the residents; burial of the corpses in a mass grave in Brzeszcze; names of [some of] the victims: Anna Weiss, Gerst (a man); a man identified by his prisoner number only; Chan Ernst, Kohn Alfred, Sauer Balthasar and Richard Werner; attempt by Gil Paran to locate details regarding the victims; memorialization of the victims via the Ernst Cahn and Alfred Kohn Bridge in [Amsterdam,] the Netherlands.

chronitem.event: Murder of Jews inDubossaryon the 12 September 1941

custodhist.p: The materials were transferred to Yad Vashem byבן ציון גסלר

scopecontent.p: Documentation regarding the experiences of the Jewish community in Dubossary during World War II; documents dated, 1988-1990 Included in the file: - List of residents of Dubossary and the Dubossary vicinity who were murdered by the Nazis, 1941; list prepared by the team established to help the restoration of the gravestone in memory of the victims of the Holocaust in Dubossary; - List of residents of Dubossary who participated in the mass murders of the local Jews; investigation reports regarding the war crimes perpetrated by Nazi war criminals and their collaborators; testimony of Nikolay Khvorostyan, who survived the murder carried out at a killing pit; testimony of Bentzin Gesler, prepared on the basis of documentation from the State Archives of Moldavia; - Poems dedicated to the Jews of Dubossary who were murdered, 1941; - Articles from the "Flag of Victory" newspaper, regarding the commemoration of the victims of the Holocaust in Dubossary; - Appeals to the residents of Dubossary by the team established to help the restoration of the gravestone in memory of the Jews of Dubossary who perished during the Holocaust.

custodhist.p: The materials were transferred to Yad Vashem byגימפלסון קטרינה

scopecontent.p: Documentation regarding David and Chaya Rivka (Levinova) Gimpelson, including notification that David Gimpelson was Missing In Action at the front, confirmation regarding the evacuation of R. Gimpelson and additional family members, work booklet of Chaya Rivka Gimpelson and more, 1928-2000 - Notification by the military commissioner in Simferopol that Red Army soldier David Gimpelson, born in Vitebsk, Russia, was Missing In Action at the front, 07/1944; the notification was sent to his wife, 05/1947. Included in the file: - Notarized copy of the notification, 19/10/1989; - Marriage certificate of David Gimpelson and Riva Levinova, issued in Simferopol, 03/08/1928; - Confirmation regarding the evacuation of R. Gimpelson, along with five of her family members, from Simferopol to Krasnodar; confirmation issued, 28/09/1941; - Work booklet issued to Chaya Rivka Gimpelson, 16/01/1939; information regarding her employment record until 1984; - Archival confirmation of the birth of Chaya Rivka Levinova, 30/05/1909, to Khatzkel and Ester Levinov; confirmation issued, 27/12/2000, based on the birth registrations of the Kronshtadt synagogue.

did.unittitle: Genealogies of the Demajo and Pijade families, and a list of relatives of Dr. Rafael Pijade who perished

custodhist.p: The materials were transferred to Yad Vashem byטל מוסקוביץ לבית פיאדה (Pijade)

scopecontent.p: Genealogies of the Demajo and Pijade families, and a list of relatives of Dr. Rafael Pijade who perished The family of the woman who submitted the documents: Her father, Rafael Rudi Pijade, born in Belgrade, Yugoslavia, 1916 (survivor); Her mother, Debora (Mandlovici), daughter of Yosef and Matilda Mandlovici, born in 1922; Her grandfather, Yechezkel Pijade, born in Belgrade, a merchant; Her grandmother Rebeca (Demajo) Pijade; Her father's sister, Lili Pijade, residence in Nis, Serbia, marriage 1940, whose husband, Shiki Varom was murdered along with other inmates outside the city on the Bobaon Mountain, 1941; Lili (Luna) was left alone and pregnant; she was transferred to Belgrade and from there to the Sajmiste camp; from there by truck to Dusegubica, and she apparently was suffocated en route; Her parents, Debora and Rafael Pijade were married in Belgrade, 1946; The family members who escaped to Albania were hidden by a Moslem family, and survived, the rest of the family perished. Also in the file: Survey of the Holocaust in Yugoslavia.

scopecontent.p: List of Jews from the Vojvodina district who earned Medals of Distinction from the Austro-Hungarian Army in World War I The album was published in advance of the Hungarian occupation during World War II in the hope that it would protect the Jews from deportation to camps. Biographical summaries of some of the men on the list appear on pp. 1608-1655, and their photographs appear on pp. 1656-1677.
The list/s contain approximately 1800 names

scopecontent.p: Documentation regarding the preparation of the Yizkor book of the Vas region, including a list of Jews from Beled who were deported to Auschwitz, 1944, where they perished - Letters written by Alice Braun Davidne to Smuel Ragendorfer, regarding the collection of names of the Jews who resided in the Vas region; - Letters sent by various people that include the names of their relatives; - Newspaper clippings regarding the Yizkor book and people connected to the publication of the book; photographs from the book; - List of Jews from Beled who were deported to Auschwitz, 1944, where they perished.

did.unittitle: Excerpt from research regarding the history of Piwniczna Zdroj, edited by Jozef Dlugosz and others

custodhist.p: The materials were transferred to Yad Vashem byדלוגוש יוזף, ורוצלב, פולין

scopecontent.p: Excerpt from research regarding the history of Piwniczna Zdroj, edited by Jozef Dlugosz and others Content (documents, chain of documents): I. File 5266046 (pp. 2-86) Documentation regarding the Jews of Nove Zamky, the Nove Zamky area and Stara Dala, including lists of Jewish residents of Nove Zamky and settlements in the Nove Zamky area, with notation regarding their fate during the Holocaust. In detail: 1) Obituaries for Reuven Ben Yakov Zvi Rudolf Fleischer, President of the Jewish community of Nové Zámky from 1935 to 1944 and from 1945 to 1956; (p. 3) 2) Handwritten document, in Hungarian, dated 29.10.1944; (p. 4) 3) ID, German, for Judith Ellenbogen, Transport Kastner, dated 20.06.1944; (p. 5) 4) Longer article, in Hebrew, about Nové Zámky on a header of the Beth Hatefutsoth; (pp. 6-9) Lists of Jewish residents of Nove Zamky and settlements in the Nove Zamky area, with notation regarding their fate during the Holocaust 5) Index of names (Szemere Semerovo) Hungarian; (pp. 10 f.) 6) Index of names (Pribeta-Perbete), Hungarian; (pp. 12-15) 7) Index of names (Komjat Komjatice), Hungarian; (pp. 16-19) 8) Index of names (Dvory Nad Zitavou Udvard), Hungarian; (pp. 16-19) 9) Index of names (Komjat Komjatice), Hungarian; (pp. 20-25) 10) Excerpt from book by Dr. Ferenc Raab, in Hungarian, regarding the history of the Jewish community of Stara Dala., Az ogyallai - hurbanovoi zsidosag törtenete; (pp. 26-34) 11) List (Hebrew) of former Jewish citizens of Nové Zámky (before the Shoah); (pp. 35 f.) 12) Map of Czechoslovakia 1918-1938 (incl. South Slovakia and Ruthenia); (p. 37) 13) Synopsis (9 lines), in Hebrew, about Nové Zámky on a header of the Beth Hatefutsoth; (p. 38) 14) Index of names, Hungarian, in alphabetical order; (pp. 39-85); 15) Copy of a pictured memorial and a text, Hebrew, telling the story of 14 youths who managed to escape from several forced labor camps but were later recaptured in hiding, tortured and murdered shorty before the liberation by the Russian army in 1945; the murderer was tried and sentenced after the war; no specification; no names, no loactions; (p. 86) II. File 5266047 (pp. 87-157) Lists of Jews, in Russian, submitted by relatives, from the Vinnitsa region, and other places, who perished, 1941-1944 In detail: 16) Indexes of names, in Russian, belonging to murdered Jewish victims from Dzhurin, Ghargorod; from Galzhbiyevka, Yampol; from Khmelnik; from Lypovets; from Nemirov; from Novaya Priluka, Turbov; from Pliskov; from Pogrebishche; from Priluki, Turbov; from Ulanov; from Vakhnovka; from the city of Vinnytsia (Ukrainian: Ві́нниця, Polish: Winnica, German: Winniza), a city in central Ukraine; all aforementioned places are located in in Vinnytsia Oblast (province); 17) Indexes of names, in Russian, belonging to murdered Jewish victims from the city of Kamenets Podolsk and Staro Konstantinov (or Starokostiantyniv (Ukrainian: Старокостянтинів), both cities in the Khmelnytskyi Oblast of Western Ukraine; 18) Comments in Russian III. File 5266048 (pp. 158-161) 19) Partial lists of Jews deported from Berettyoszentmarton and Berettyoujfalu, 1944; index of Jewish names in Hungarian; IV. File 5266050 (pp. 162-170) 20) List of Jews who perished in the Nekla camp, 04-08/1942; index of Jewish names in Polish; 21) Correspondence between Arie Goldstein (submitter of the material) and the head of the Nekla Jewish community, and the Regional Commission for the Prosecution of Crimes Against the Polish Nation in Poznan, 1987-1990, with additional information regarding the Nekla camp, including its establishment and murder of the Jews in 1942; V. File 5266051 (pp. 171-236) List of Jewish inmates from Czechoslovakia in Sered camp, 01/1944; most of the inmates were transferred, apparently to Auschwitz, 09/01/1944; In detail: 22) Handwritten fax, in English, dated 01.11.2004; request to Yad Vashem in assisting the sender to loacte her grandparents birth certificate; (p. 172) 23) List of Jewish victimes from Slovakian towns in camp Sered, Slovakia; index of Jewish names; (p. 173-236) VI. File 5266051 (pp. 237-302) This is the same file under V. scanned twice. VII. File 5266052 (pp. 303-306) List of Jews with Swiss bank accounts during World War II, prepared by the Claims Conference 24) Article "Swiss Banks Commence Global Claims Process to Identify Owners of Dormant World War II-Era Accounts", New York Times, 23.07.1997; alphabetical list of account holder names; VIII. File 5266107 (pp. 307-314) Official documentation regarding Anna Clara (Lewin) Gruenstein, her husband, Hermann Gruenstein, and their son, Ludwig Gruenstein, from Berlin who perished, 31 December 1942 In detail: 25) Death Certificate of Anna Clara Grünstein, née Lewin, born 14.03.1892 in Berlin; her date of death is assessed for December 31, 1942, decreed by the Court of Berlin-Charlottenburg on September 11, 1951; (p. 309) 26) Birth Certificate of Ludwig Heinrich Grünstein (born 27.01.1933 in Berlin); (p. 309) 27) Death Certificate of Hermann Grünstein, born 15.04.1891 in Johannisburg, East Prussia; his date of death is assessed for December 31, 1942, decreed by the Court of Berlin-Charlottenburg on October 11, 1951; (p. 310) 28) Death Certificate of Ludwig Grünstein, born 27.01.1933 in Berlin; his date of death is assessed for December 31, 1942, decreed by the Court of Berlin-Charlottenburg on October 29, 1951; (p. 310) 29) Typewritten, unsigned essay regarding "my sister's economical situation" with biographical details about Anna Clara Grünstein, the wife of Hermann Grünstein; conflicting data since the author mentions that Clara Grünstein was first deported to Theresienstadt in 1943 and then to Auschwitz in October 1944; (p. 311) 30) Wedding Certificate of a civil marriage ceremony between Anna Clara Lewin and Hermann Grünstein on December 27, 1919; (p. 312) 31) Birth Certificate of Anna Clara Lewin; (p. 313 f.) IX. File 5266110 (pp. 315-322) pdf in 5266110 not linked Copies of the Death certificates of the members of Heinsen family from Hamburg who perished in the Holocaust. In detail: 32) Death Certificate of Martha Olga Heinsen (Heymannsohn), née Herzfeld, born 06.07.1872 in Berlin; her date of death is assessed for December 31, 1945, decreed by the Court of Berlin-Charlottenburg on June 08, 1960; (p. 315) 33) Assessment of a survivorship annuity for Wolfgang Heinsen; (p. 316) 34) Assessment of time of death of Fritz Heinsen (assessed for January 15, 1951) for Wolfgang Heinsen; document only partly legible; (p. 317) 35) Family register of Martha Olga Heinsen (Heymannsohn), née Herzfeld, issued on August 8, 1913 by the authorities of the Canton Zurich, Switzerland; (pp. 318-320) 36) Family register of Fritz Heinsen (Heymannsohn), born 01.11.1896 in Berlin; (pp. 321 f.) X. File 5266111 (pp. 323-335) 37) Partial list of Jews deported from Dej, used in the gettoization of 03-10/05/1944; the list includes the names of the submitter's family members; the names of the submitter's family members are: Stern Geza, Stern Gizi, Stern Reli; ten photographs of the submitter's family members; the photographs were transferred to the Yad Vashem Photo Archive; Archival Signature 5849; painting of Stern Reli when she was 11 years old, before her deportation from Dej, 1944; the painting was transferred to the Yad Vashem Art Museum, accession number 3925; XI. File 5266116 (pp. 336-341) 38) Museum Auschwitz, letter, in Polish, with a partial list of Jewish inmates in Auschwitz (incl. the inmates' numbers) to Pan Aharon Gluska, New York, on June 18, 1995; (pp. 336-341) XII. File 5266131 (pp. 342-354) 39) Lists of Jewish inmates (in Czech and in German) in Schwarzheide camp who perished, 1944-1945; the list includes name, birthday, date of death, last address; (pp. 349-352) 40) Letter from the Federal President's Office, Germany, dated June 13, 1997, to the Czech citizens Richard Svoboda and Jri Lom regarding their correspondence of May 29, 1997; handwritten note in Czech on the bottom of the letter; (p. 353) 41) Letter, in Czech, September 20, 1997; (p. 354 f.) XIII File 5266132 (pp. 355-391) Clippings from a local newspaper from Rechitsa, Belarus, including lists of local Jews who were murdered in Rechitsa, or who died in the war 42) Russian language Belarus Newspaper Dnyaprovets, from Rechytsa (Belarusian: Рэчыца, Russian: Речица, Polish: Rzeczyca), a town in the Homiel Province of Belarus; several editions, starting of July 1st, 1993; list of Jewish and non-Jewish victims, murdered by Germans, articles and short biographical notes about the victims and the events; (pp. 356-391) XIV File 5266135 (pp. 392-422) 43) Lists of Jews from Polonnoye, Poninka, Novolabun, and Vorobyevka, who perished, 1941-1942; the file includes a historical survey on the communities and pictures of the sites; parts are difficult to read, even illegible due to the poor quality of the copies; XV File 5266137 (pp. 423-488) 44) Lists of Jews in the Korelichi Ghetto, 20/5/1942, and Jews from Yaremichi who perished; the original is housed in the Grodno Regional Archive; under F.641, op.2,d.3; the file also includes general information about Mir and Korelichi during the Holocaust. XVI File 5266143 (pp. 489 f.) 45) Confirmation (in Russian) that Josef Teitelbaum, M.D. from Yugoslavia, died in a military hospital from weakness on 29/5/45 after the Red Army liberated him from Troebitz'; XVII File 5266218 (pp. 491-498) 46) List of Jews from Shatsk who perished, 1941-1944, and list of victims of the Soviet authority from Shatsk (documents in Russian); Shatsk (Ukrainian: Шацьк, Polish: Szack) is a small town in Ukraine, in Volyn Oblast, to the north-west of Kovel; not to be confused with Shatsk in Russia; XVIII File 5266227 (pp. 499-509) 47) Lists of Jews in Orel, 1941-43; lists from 1942 were given to the German authorities by the Jundenrat (documents in Russian); Oryol or Orel, a city and the administrative center of Oryol Oblast was occupied by the Wehrmacht on October 3, 1941, and liberated on August 5, 1943, after the Battle of Kursk (documents in Russian); XIX File 5266234 (pp. 510-519) 48) List of Jews who were deported to the Siauliai Ghetto (as a result of census questionnaires in Latvian and German), among them the Sinseris family who perished; a confirmation that Isaak Sinseris, Red Army soldier, died of mortal wounds in a military hospital during May, 1943; a poem in Yiddish, written by Isaak Sinseris Isaak during his military service in 1943; photograph's of Isaak Sinseris; only two pages (the list) has been linked to 5266234; XX File 5266261 (pp. 520-724) 49) Handwritten list in Russian of German Nazis and war criminals; 50) List of Jews from the Horodenka district, the Zabolotow and Kuty regions, Bolczowce, and Pistin, who perished; XXI File 5266274 (pp. 725-736) Birth certificates, and a list of the Kreps family members from Wloszczowa who were murdered in Treblinka and Skarzysko Kamienna camps, 1942-1943; In detail: 51) Copy of the birth certificate of the submitter of the material, Kay Louis (Szyja Kreps Lejbus); 52) Copy of her parents' marriage certificate; note: the list of the people who were murdered was prepared by the submitter of the material;

did.unittitle: Documentation regarding the Jewish community of Teofipol

custodhist.p: The materials were transferred to Yad Vashem byHorowitz Louis

scopecontent.p: Documentation regarding the Jewish community of Teofipol Included in the file: - Lists of Jews from Teofipol and Bazaliya who were murdered, 1942; - Article by Manus Yadishlivy, "Chupa at the Cemetery," regarding the murder of Jews of Bazaliya, 1942, pp. 71-73; - Lists of Jews in Teofipol, taken from the population censuses of 1926 and 1928; - Excerpts from the book by Eliyahu Cherikover, "The Ukrainian Pogrom in 1919", New York, 1965, [Yiddish], regarding the pogrom in Chan (also known as: Teofipol) and the surrounding settlements in 1919; Yad Vashem Library call number 65-509; pp. 133-172; - Article by I. A. Stasyuk regarding the history of the Jewish community of Teofipol, pp. 176-187; - Photographs of the Jewish cemetery in Teofipol; deciphering of the inscriptions on the graves, pp. 190-200.

did.unittitle: Card file of Jews who perished in the Ebensee camp hospital, and two notebooks with names of Jews who perished in the camp, 1944-1945

scopecontent.p: Card file of Jews who perished in the hospital of the Ebensee camp, and two notebooks with names of Jews who perished in the camp, 1944-1945 The card file includes cards with names, dates (apparently date of admission to the hospital and date of death, and sometimes also dates of treatments), and diagnosis or cause of death. The materials were given to Yad Vashem by Albert Halm who was deported from Carpathian Ruthenia to Auschwitz and Ebensee when he was 18 years old. In Ebensee he was employed cleaning the Revier, the camp hospital - which was adjacent to the crematorium. Attached to the foot of each bunk was a slip of paper with information regarding the patient and his illness. Albert Halm collected these notes from the bunks of patients who had died and hid them for 14 months, until the liberation.
The list/s contain approximately 3915 names

The list/s contain approximately 611 names

did.unittitle: List of Jews deported from Bielefeld to various extermination camps

custodhist.p: The materials were transferred to Yad Vashem byדקר בריגיטה, דקר מרטין בילפלד, גרמניה

scopecontent.p: List of Jews deported from Bielefeld to various extermination camps Jews whose names appear on this list were deported from Lippe, Schaumburg-Lippe and the Minden district, and were concentrated in Bielefeld where they were separated and sent to the following extermination camps: Buchenwald, 12.11.1938 Riga, 13.12.1941 Warschau, 31.03.1942 Auschwitz, 11.07.1942 and 02.03.1943 Theresienstadt, 31.07.1942, 12.05.1943, 28.06.1943 and 13.02.1945 Elben and Zeitz, 19.09.1944 The names on the list were copied from a memorial plaque located in the central railroad station in Bielefeld. Schaumburg-Lippe existed until 1946, when it became one of the districts of Lower Saxony. Schaumburg and Schaumburg-Lippe were districts of Lower Saxony until they were merged again in 1977.
The list/s contain approximately 1840 names

scopecontent.p: List of Jews from Grinkiskis who were murdered in Krakes, 02/09/1941 Information regarding the murder of Grinkiskis Jews by Lithuanians was received from a Jew in Grinkiskis named Reibshtein, who escaped to hiding in a forest; Experiences of the submitter of the material, Yaakov Levi: His escape from Grinkiskis to Latvia, 1941; escape to Russia, the Soviet Union, 1942; draft into the 16th Lithuanian Division; life in the Lithuanian Division, battalion no. 156; life in Alekseyevka including combat, summer 1943; wounded and taken captive by the Germans; rescue by Russian workers in the hospital in Orel.
The list/s contain approximately 30 names

scopecontent.p: Documentation regarding the fate of the Jews of Sabac and Jewish refugees from Austria, Germany and Czechoslovakia who were detained in the Sabac camp and murdered in the Zasavica camp, October 1941 Also in the file: - Announcement regarding the death of the parents of the submitter of the material (p. 1852); - Sketch of the Jewish camp in Sabac (p. 1858); - Article by Lubomir Vukodinovic regarding the fate of the Jewish soccer player Kurt Hilkovic (p. 1859), 1967; - Excerpt from the book "Wir packen, Wir auspacken (We Pack, We Unpack)" by Mara Jovanovic, regarding the fate of the Jewish refugees from Austria, Germany and Czechoslovakia who arrived in Sabac with the hope of continuing on to Eretz Israel from there (pp. 1860-1888).

Also in the file: - Excerpts from lists of the deportees to Theresienstadt and to the Minsk Ghetto, including Gertrud Hechscher, sister of Leon Cohen; - Letter written by Dr. Daniel Cohen regarding the experiences of members of the Cohen family from Altona and their fate; - Photograph of a Holy Ark carved by Leon Daniel Cohen in 1939 that today is displayed at the Yad Vashem Museum.

scopecontent.p: Letter from the Military Kommissar, dated, 08 January 1942, regarding the circumstances of the death of Red Army soldier Semyon Lifshitz, and a notarized copy of the announcement that Semyon Lifshitz was killed in action, sent to his wife, 02 December 1941 - Notarized copy of the announcement that Red Army soldier Semyon Lifshitz was killed in action at the front in the war, at the Sheremetyevo station near Ryazhsk; the announcement was sent to his wife, 02 December 1941 (the notarized copy was issued, 17 February 1984, and the copy is dated, 17 August 1990); - Letter sent to Lyubov Lifshitz by the Military Kommissar, including a description of the circumstances of the death of her husband Semyon Lifshitz, who had been the Military Kommissar of a sanitation train [which delivered relief supplies and provided medical care to the wounded], and who was killed during air-raids on the train by the Germans, while he was attempting to evacuate the wounded; letter dated, 08 January 1942; Comments by the submitter of the material (Maya Lifshitz): Semyon Lifshitz was born in 1906. Before the war, he resided in Bobruysk with his family: his wife Lyubov and his daughters Maya, Nina and Lena. He was the secretary of the Communist Party in the region. At the outbreak of the war, he was drafted into the Red Army and was killed in December 1941. During the war, his wife and daughters were evacuated to Saransk and after the liberation of Belorussia, they returned to the family's home.

scopecontent.p: Copy of the notice from the military Commissariat in Kirov, 15 April 1944, regarding the disappearance of the Red Army soldier Pinya Kravetz, born in the Zhitomir region, at the war front, September 1942 The copy was issued on 10 December 1946. Notes from the woman who submitted the material: Pinya Kravetz was born in Narodichi, and worked in a factory in Kiev before the war. At the outbreak of the war he was drafted to the Red Army; he disappeared at the front in the Stalingrad area, September1942.

custodhist.p: The materials were transferred to Yad Vashem byBespechny Polina

scopecontent.p: Documentation regarding the wounding in battle of Red Army soldier Ilya Bondarevsky, born in Vinnitsa, and his death from his wounds, August 1944; letters sent by his comrades in arms to his sister in Vinnitsa regarding the circumstances of his death Original documents: - Notarized copy of the notice dated 06 September 1944 regarding the wounding of Ilya Bondarevsky at the front and his death, 29 August 1944; - Letter from the People's Commissariat for the Defense of the Soviet Union to Leib Bondarevsky, the father of Ilya Bondarevsky, in Vinnitsa announcing that his son Ilya Bondarevsky does not appear on the list of wounded and dead, 13 December 1944. Scanned documents: - Confirmation given to Blyuma Bondarevsky, 13 July 1941, regarding the draft of her son Ilya Bondarevsky to the Red Army, 23 June 1941; - Confirmation from 1943 regarding the evacuation of Leib Bondarevsky together with the rest of the population before the occupation by the Germans, August 1943; - Notice of the wounding of Ilya Bondarevsky at the front, his death from his wounds, 29 August 1944 and his burial in the cemetery in the town of Rayul, 31 August 1944 (The notice was sent to Ilya Bondarevsky's father by the commander of the unit in which the son served, 06 September 1944); - Confirmation from the workers in the shoe factory in Vinnitsa of the employment of Ilya Bondarevsky's brother Iosif Bondarevsky from 1936 and until the time he was drafted to the Red Army in1941. Letters sent by comrades in arms of Ilya Bondarevsky to his sister Lyusya containing notices regarding his wounding in battle and his death from his wounds in August 1944 (scan): - Letter regarding the circumstances under which Ilya was wounded, and of his death, undated; - Letter sent by Aleksandr Nechayev to Lyusya Bondarevsky in Vinnitsa, 14 September 1944, regarding the wounding of Ilya Bondarevsky in battle, 31 August 1944; - Letter written 01 November 1944 regarding the wounding of Ilya Bondarevsky in battle , 29 August 1944, and his death from his wounds en route to the hospital. Notes from the person who submitted the material: The Bondarevsky family lived in Vinnitsa before the war. The parents Leib and Blyuma (Rek) Bondarevsky escaped to the East with their daughter Libsha (Lyusya) in 1941. Leib Bondarevsky disappeared when he left the train for a moment (apparently en route back to Vinnitsa in 1944). Two sons, Gedalia (Grisha) and Ilya were drafted to the Red Army. Ilya was killed at the front and Gedalia died after the war. The third son, Iosif, worked in a factory and disappeared even before he could be drafted to the Red Army. Libsha (Lyusya) made aliya to Israel in 1991.

scopecontent.p: Personal documentation belonging to Stera Brukhanskaya including her birth certificate and a letter sent by the municipal council in Mena - Letter sent to Stera Brukhanskaya in Tashkent by the municipal council in Mena notifying her of the murder of her parents by the Germans, 20 April 1944; the letter was sent in reaction to a letter sent by Stera; - Birth certificate of Stera Brukhanskaya, born in Mena, Ukraine, 1923; her parents were Leib and Maria Brukhanski. Notes from the submitter of the material: Stera Brukhanskaya's father, Leib Brukhanski was born in Konotop, Ukraine in 1899; her mother, Maria, was born in 1898. In 1940 Stera moved from Mena to Depropetrovsk to continue her studies; from there she was transferred along with the rest of the population in 1941. Stera moved to Rostov to a brother of her father's who was serving in the Red Army. Later she moved from Rostov to Khachmas with her aunt, and from there to Tashkent. Her parents remained in Mena. Her father was drafted into the Red Army, was taken captive and returned to his home town where he was murdered together with his wife in December 1941.

scopecontent.p: Notice sent to Sonya Sharifker in Birobidzhan regarding the disappearance of her husband, Leyzar Sharifker, at the war front, 29 August 1942 Notes from Boris Sharifker who submitted the material: Eliezer Sharifker was born in 1911. His family lived in Chudnov. He moved to Birobidzhan together with his wife, Sonya (Kaplan). Their two children, Boris (who submitted the material), born in 1937, and Moisey, born in 1940 were born in Birobidzhan. At the outbreak of the war, Eliezer and his brother Grigoriy were drafted to the Red Army. In 1942 the family received notification that Eliezer had disappeared at the front. Grigoriy survived, and started a family in Tashkent after the war.

did.unittitle: Lists of those who perished and those who were deported from the Johanngeorgenstadt, Gross-Rosen, Auschwitz, Buchenwald and Flossenburg camps, 1944-1945, testimonies against German war criminals submitted by Arje Ferleger, 1945-1947 and post-war period investigative reports regarding the Johanngeorgenstadt camp

custodhist.p: The materials were transferred to Yad Vashem byמרים הלפר

scopecontent.p: Lists of those who perished and those who were deported from the Johanngeorgenstadt, Gross-Rosen, Auschwitz, Buchenwald and Flossenburg camps, 1944-1945, testimonies against German war criminals submitted by Arje Ferleger, 1945-1947 and post-war period investigative reports regarding the Johanngeorgenstadt camp Lists: - List of 500 Jewish inmates transferred from Auschwitz in order to employ them in the German building project, Riese (a sub camp of Gross-Rosen), 29 September 1944; - List of 50 Jews who perished in Auschwitz, 1943-1944; - List containing the names of 206 Jewish inmates transferred to Auschwitz-Birkenau compiled by SS Sturmscharfurer Schafer at the Buchenwald camp, 26 October 1944; - List of Polish inmates who perished in the Flossenburg and Johanngeorgenstadt camps, 1944-1945; - List of inmates (apparently Ukrainian) who perished in the Flossenburg and Johanngeorgenstadt camps, 1944-1945; - List of seven non-Jewish inmates from various countries (some of them from France) who perished from illnesses in the Flossenburg and Johanngeorgenstadt camps, 1944-1945; - List of 51 Jews from the Netherlands who died from typhus in Troebitz, 23 May-18 June 1945, and were buried in the Brandenburg area; - List of 11 Jews from France, Poland, Greece, Albania and Yugoslavia who died from typhus in Troebitz, 23 May-18 June 1945; - List of 50 Jewish inmates from Hungary who perished in the Gross-Rosen camp, 1945; - List of 115 Jewish inmates from the Netherlands, Greece, the Soviet Union, Slovakia, Czechia, France, Belgium, Italy and Germany who perished in the Riese camp (a sub camp of Gross-Rosen), 1945 (the list also includes three stateless inmates); - List of 273 Jewish inmates of unknown citizenship who perished in the Riese camp, 1945; - Handwritten list of 10 German officers who served in camps or participated in organizing the transports with a note regarding their jobs (the connection between them is not clear); - Handwritten list of 12 Jews (in what connection the list was compiled is not clear). Testimonies: - Testimony of Arje Ferleger at the trial against the war criminal, Andree Bruno, held in Dobelrug, 03 September 1945; - Letter sent by Arje Ferleger to Red Army Headquarters in Auerbach with testimony regarding the confiscation of the property of the Jews of Poland, 02 October 1942; - Testimony regarding the mass murder of Jews in Sosnovice, 03 September 1939 (It is not clear when and from whom the testimony was taken); - Details regarding the "Aktion" in Bendzin, 01 August 1943; - Letter sent by Arje Ferleger to the Polish Military Legation in Berlin with testimony against the war criminal, Karl Jenzen, who was involved in the mass murder of Jews in Bendzin, and against his associate, Dr. Mildner, 07 October 1947; - Investigative report of Paul Groeger at the Johanngeorgenstadt Police, 22 August 1945; testimony of Paul Groeger regarding the Soviet physician named Georg who escaped from the Johanngeorgenstadt camp and in the course of his escape killed two Kapos - one whose last name was Brick, and the other, Otto Gibb, 22 August 1945. Reports: - Report submitted by Dr. Danke regarding autopsies performed on corpses exhumed from a common grave (50 corpses) and from individual graves (14 corpses) in the cemetery in Johanngeorgenstadt, according to which the people suffered from hunger, and were beaten and tortured before they died, 25-26 October 1945; - Report submitted by the Johanngeorgenstadt Police, 07 March 1946, regarding the transport of inmates from Wildenthal to the Johanngeorgenstadt camp, 15 April 1945; the transport from Wildenthal was comprised of two transports that departed from Lengenfeld and from Zwickauer; the names of two SS officers and Volkssturm (German National Militia) assistants who were involved in the organization of the transports. Other documentation: - Application submitted by Adolf Ferleger to the District Authorities in Auerbach, 10 October 1945, requesting permission to bring in railroad cars containing the equipment necessary for his factory; Ferleger's experiences during the war; Ferleger's statement that he is the only one who remained in Germany of all the deportees from Hungary, Romania, Yugoslavia and more, and that he personally gave assistance to 14,000 people who were deported during the war to return to their places of origin; - Confirmation that Adolf Ferleger, residing in Falkenstein, was a victim of fascism, issued by the Office for the Treatment of Victims of Fascism in Auerbach, 26 April 1946; - Official letter sent from Johanngeorgenstadt to Adolf Ferleger in Berlin confirming receipt of documents sent by Ferleger, 05 September 1947; - Correspondence and documents regarding business matters of Adolf Ferleger (textile manufacture and wholesaling) from the postwar period; - Confirmations given to various people in Wuestegiersdorf regarding hospitalization in the Stohr Hospital in Wuestegiersdorf, May-June 1945 (in Polish and German), 29 June 1945; - Permit to reside in Berlin issued by the Berlin police to Rose Ferleger (the wife of Adolf Ferleger), 31 August 1946. Notes from Miriam Halper who submitted the material: Arje (Adolf) Ferleger was born in Bendzin, 20 December, 1911; he attended school in Berlin. His parents were Yitzchak and Miriam (Friedman) Ferleger. Yitzchak Ferleger died in Berlin in 1928. There were eight children in the family, and only two of them survived the Holocaust - Arje and Yisrael. In December 1933 Arje married Rose Tropauer; in 1938 all men thought to be Polish Jews were deported to Poland, and afterwards the women joined them as well. After the outbreak of the war, Arje Ferleger and his family were transferred to the Bendzin Ghetto. Arje succeeded in smuggling his wife and son, Yitzchak Meier, from there to Berlin, and he arrived there by himself afterwards. They escaped to Hungary where they were caught and deported to Auschwitz. Arje was sent from Auschwitz to Gross-Rosen, and from there to Riese, one of the Gross-Rosen sub camps. Due to his excellent knowledge of the German language, he was employed as a secretary. In Riese he secretly recorded lists of those who perished and those who were deported in order to preserve them. After the war, Arje continued to live in Germany and to work for the memorialization of the Jews who were murdered.

scopecontent.p: List of Jewish family members from Lask who perished during the Holocaust, with the exception of Abram Szlomo Pukacz who appears as No. 25 on the list Also in the file: Photocopy of a photograph of students at the Tarbut School in Lask (academic year 1938-1939), among them Abram Szlomo Pukacz and his sister Ester Sajndal who perished in the Holocaust (she appears as No. 29 on the list). Notes from Abram Szlomo Pukacz, who submitted the material: Abram Szlomo Pukacz was born in Lask on 15 October 1926. During the war he was a forced laborer in a coal mine in Fuerstengrube. On 16 August 1944 he arrived in Auschwitz. Afterwards he was taken on a death march to Nordhausen and liberated by the US Army. His sister, who was born in 1927, perished, as well as all the members of his family.
The list/s contain approximately 64 names

did.unittitle: Names of those who perished listed on a memorial wall, including members of the Davoretski and Trotski family who were murdered in Iwie and Korelichi, 1942

custodhist.p: The materials were transferred to Yad Vashem byלובה רם Luba Ram

scopecontent.p: Names of those who perished listed on a memorial wall, including members of the Davoretski and Trotski family who were murdered in Iwie and Korelichi, 1942 - Names of those who perished listed on a memorial wall, including the names of members of the Davoretski and Milikovski family who were murdered by the Germans in Iwie, 12 May 1942, and the name of Chaim Lyuka Davoretski who fell in the War of Independence; - Names of those who perished listed on a memorial wall, including the names of members of the Trotski family who were murdered by the Germans in Korelichi, 06 August 1942, and the name of Reb Shmuel the son of Reb Zahav Trotski who died in 5875 (1915). Notes from Luba (Davoretski) Ram who submitted the material: Luba (Davoretski) Ram was born in Iwie, 28 January 1928. She lived in Iwie in the same house with her grandparents Meir and Gitta Davoretski, her uncle Shmuel and his wife Esther Rachel and their children Asher (Oskeh) and Chaim Leibeleh (Lyuka), her parents Chaim Lev and Teibel Yona Davoretski and her sister Zillah. The family dealt in agricultural mechanical equipment and building supplies. The children attended the Tarbut School in the village. The Soviets occupied the city in 1939, and nationalized all the businesses, as well as confiscating part of the house. The Germans occupied the village in September 1941. In the beginning the Jews were enclosed in a specific area of Iwie. They received families from nearby villages and they were allowed to go around freely. On the ninth day of Av (02 August) 1941, the Germans murdered most of the members of the Intelligentsia of the village including her uncle Shmuel, the high school principal and the rabbi. Her father worked for a blacksmith who blackened her father's face and the Germans thought he was a laborer. In May 1942 there was an "Aktion"; the residents of the village were gathered together in a large field opposite her house. The whole family was taken there, including her uncle David and her aunt Batya Milikovski, their daughter Mirka and their son Bezalel (Zelka). At a certain junction there was a tall officer with a dog together with soldiers who pointed to the left, to the right and straight without the family understanding what was happening. Her father, mother, sister and Luba received orders to go to the right, her grandfather and grandmother and the Milikovski family were sent down the street and her aunt Esther Rachel and the boys were ordered to the left. Her father carried Chaim Labeleh, her cousin, with them. At the end of the day, after they had sat for hours on the ground, they were sent behind the stores. Every few families were directed to a specific house. The crowding was great and the area was announced as being "the ghetto". When the ghetto was liquidated, they were taken to the Lida Ghetto, and her father worked for the Germans. Life was very hard in the ghetto. When her father heard that Tuvia Bielski, whom he had known preciously, had set up a Jewish partisan unit, he tried to make contact with Bielski and was successful. Bielski told him to come with his family even if they did not have weapons and thus they joined the unit of Tuvia Bielski. They were liberated in 1944, and returned to the village, and they found that just a few of the residents had arrived. They found maybe 24 Jews who had survived. No one was left of the family. Their big house was still standing and her parents decided not to approach the house and they went to live on the other side of the village with the widow of the local magistrate. Luba and her sister went to school and had to learn with collaborators[?]. In May 1945 Luba's teacher knocked on the door and announced that the war had ended, and that is when her father decided to make aliya to Eretz Israel. On the train, they bribed the soldiers and arrived in Lodz. They made contact with emissaries from Eretz Israel and made aliya with Aliya Bet via Hungary, Romania and Czechoslovakia, arriving in Italy in 1945. There they boarded the ship, "Dov Hos". They arrived in Eretz Israel in May 1946. She went to Kiryat Chaim with her parents, sister and Chaim Labeleh. Chaim Labeleh fell in battle in 5708 (1948) during the War of Independence; he was part of the Yechiam Convoy.
The list/s contain approximately 15 names

did.unittitle: Copy of the notice sent to Blyuma Kogan in Tashkent, 14 May 1946, regarding the disappearance of her husband Yankel Kogan, born in the Bykhov district, at the war front, February 1942

controlaccess.subject: Jewish soldiers in the Red Army
Murder of family and acquaintances
Evacuation

custodhist.p: The materials were transferred to Yad Vashem byפירה קוגן

scopecontent.p: Copy of the notice sent to Blyuma Kogan in Tashkent, 14 May 1946, regarding the disappearance of her husband Yankel Kogan, born in the Bykhov district, at the war front, February 1942 The copy of the notice was issued in Tashkent, 10 April 1994. Also in the file: Confirmation from the Soviet Red Cross from 15 December 1994 regarding the evacuation of Blyuma Kogan, who had lived in Mogilev before the war with her four daughters (Galya, born in 1927, Roza, born in 1929, Fira, born in 1932 and Nina, born in 1939) to Grachyovka in the Chkalov district, 03 July 1941. Notes from Fira Kogan who submitted the material: Yaakov (Yankel) Kogan, his wife Blyuma (Yoffe) and their four daughters lived in Mogilev. When the war broke out, the family was evacuated to the Chkalov area and from there they moved to Tashkent. Blyuma Kogan and her daughters remained in Tashkent until the end of the war and continued to live there until 1993. Yaakov Kogan was drafted to the Red Army and sent to the front. Since then, there has been no further trace of him.

scopecontent.p: Copy of a notification regarding the disappearance of Anatoliy Rabkin, born in Bobruysk, 1910, at the front during the war, August 1944; notification sent to his wife, 26 December 1946 Comments by the submitter of the material, Zila Rabkin: Anatoliy Rabkin was born in 1910; his wife was Fanya (Nisenbaum) Rabkin; the couple had two daughters, Zila and Klara; Zila (the submitter of the material) was the firstborn daughter; before the war, Anatoliy worked in the orphanage where he grew up; after the outbreak of the war, Anatoliy was drafted into the Red Army and died in battle at the front; the remainder of the family members escaped in the direction of Ural and resided in Izhevsk during the war.

did.unittitle: Lists of Mauthausen inmates treated in the camp hospital prepared by Dr. Zoltan Klar, a former inmate of the camp and hospital director

controlaccess.subject: The sick in the camps
Jewish physicians with the partisans in Ukraine during World War II

custodhist.p: The materials were transferred to Yad Vashem byJohn Fried, YIVO

scopecontent.p: Lists of Mauthausen inmates treated in the camp hospital prepared by Dr. Zoltan Klar, a former inmate of the camp and hospital director Appended to the lists is a letter from Y. Fried describing the circumstances under which these lists were created. The file includes the clandestine medical documents kept by the Hungarian Dr. Klar in the “Jewish Hospital” in Mauthausen. File includes: 1. Six “Zugangsbuecher”(Books of Admission to the hospital) 2. "Totenbuch” I, II and III (books in which the death of victims is registered) . 3. Dr. Klar's “Tagebuecher” (diaries) with details of Dr.Klar’s patients. 4. Copies of the printed forms Dr.Klar was required to fill out with false information concerning fictitious patients in the “Jewish Hospital”, Mauthausen, 03/1945. The intention was to show these “professional” medical histories to the International Red Cross Committee Commission that was expected to come for an inspection. They never actually arrived. 5. Farewell letter written by Adolf Katz, who handed it to Laszlé Kreisler, who was supposed to give it to Dr.Klar to bring it to Katz’s mother in Budapest. The letter is dated 18/08/1945. The “Zugangsbuecher” and “Tagebuecher” cover the period between 06/1944 and 05/1945, the “Totenbuecher” covers the period between 12/02/1945-05/05/1945.

did.unittitle: Notification by the Uzbekistan Ministry of the Defense that Yakov Mashkovich was killed in action at the front during the war, 1943, sent to his daughter Stella Chernova, 07 May 1999

controlaccess.subject: Jewish soldiers in the Red Army
Death certificates

custodhist.p: The materials were transferred to Yad Vashem byסטלה צ'רנובה

scopecontent.p: Notification by the Uzbekistan Ministry of the Defense that Yakov Mashkovich was killed in action at the front during the war, 1943, sent to his daughter Stella Chernova, 07 May 1999 Included in the file: Soviet identity card of Yan (Yakov) Mashkovich, issued during the 1930s, including details regarding his places of work and residence in Fergana and Tashkent; Comments by the submitter of the material (Stella Chernova); Yan (Yakov) Mashkovich was born in Uzbekistan, to the family of David Mashkovich, the conductor of a Red Army orchestra, who arrived to Uzbekistan from Kalish and was married to Berta Zrovinska; the family had three children: Yan, Lev and Raisa; Yan, like his father, was drafted into the Red Army and served as the conductor in a military orchestra; he married Ana Belyakova, 1934; their daughter Stella was born, 1936, and their son Yuri was born, 1937; the family resided in Fergana; Yan was assigned to the Armored Corps and was sent to the front, early 1942; he arrived home for a brief visit on Stella's birthday, early 1943; he was killed shortly after his return to the front.
